newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan central bank lowers '97 inflation forecast.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan central bank lowers '97 inflation forecast.

text.p: Taiwan's central bank on Wednesday revised its forecast for 1997 growth of the consumer price index to 3.0 percent from 3.31 percent, citing lower than expected inflation in January and February.

"Since the consumer price index in January and February came in lower than expected, we have lowered our CPI forecast to around 3.0 percent," said Chien Chi-ming, the central bank's economic research chief.

Until Wednesday, the central bank had doggedly resisted calls from other cabinet agencies to lower its 3.31 percent 1997 CPI forecast, saying such a revision was not realistic in view of Taiwan's slower-than-expected recovery.
The picture of Taiwan's economic health has improved in recent weeks, with fourth quarter gross domestic product coming in well higher than official forecasts at 6.62 percent.

On Wednesday morning, the state statistics bureau brought more encouraging news -- saying the consumer price index had risen just 2.03 percent year-on-year in February, lower than the 2.54 percent average forecast compiled in a Reuters Poll of Taiwan economists.
January's annual CPI rise came in even lower at 1.96, far below economists' forecast of an average 3.18 percent rise.
The central bank said the low-inflation trend should continue despite the gradual inflationary effects of an average nine percent price increase for domestic oil products implemented on January 1.
"The biggest factor contributing to inflation would be domestic oil prices," the central bank said in a statement.
"Domestic consumer prices should continue to remain stable barring irregular psychological expectations of an increase," it said.
Factors ensuring low inflation included falling prices for international crude oil and agricultural products, it said.
